newsitem.title: USA: Airlines raise domestic fares 2.5 percent.
newsitem.headline: Airlines raise domestic fares 2.5 percent.

text.p: Strong demand for air travel led to a 2.5 percent increase in air fares by most major airlines over the weekend, matching an increase initiated by Continental Airlines Inc. last week.
"We've seen a tremendous demand this summer and our advanced bookings for the fall are looking strong," said Jackie Pate, a spokeswoman for Delta Air Lines Inc.
The fare hikes come on top of the 10 percent federal passenger excise tax reinstated in August, which had prompted some airlines to increase their fares 10 percent.
The lone exception was Southwest Airlines Co.
"It was just a business decision. We are the low-fare airline," said Southwest spokeswoman Linda Rutherford.
In August some airlines raised their fares by 10 percent to cover the excise tax, but the fare hike did not stick because it was not uniformly matched by all carriers.
Airlines that said they raised their fares over the weekend are Trans World Airlines Inc., United Airlines, Northwest Airlines Corp. and USAir Group Inc.
The airlines also cited rising fuel costs and the expense of increased security as reasons for the fare hike.
They said the fare increase applied to domestic flights on most routes that do not compete with Southwest Airlines.
Southwest said it absorbed the cost of the excise tax on most of its routes, except for longer flights, and has so far chosen not to make additional fare increases.
"We know that the resumption of the (excise) tax will definitely impact profits, but we don't know by how much yet," Rutherford added.
